reviewText: This review was a close call for me, but I cant recommend the game right now. I love the style of the game, of course it reminds of games like Metal Slug and so on, but that doesn't make up for the repetitive and frustrating gameplay. There is a hub with missions, merchants and weapon crafting NPCs and things like that, which is cool, but the missions get way too annoying after a while. Especially because they use the same maps over and over, making you explore it again and again to get all the objectives done. What also drives me crazy is that enemies respawn all the time in the way of super old games like Ninja Gaiden, go too far in one direction and the enemy respawns is just not a good way in my opinion. The crafting system is cool, but doesn't really adds that much to the game. I really really wanted to like this game, but the repetitiveness and dull gameplay just can't convince me at all to recommend the game. I know its in beta, but they would need to change a lot to make up for it, which just isn't realistic. PS: Make the god damn multiplayer work at least...

reviewText:
summary of this game:
a half baked attempt to recreate the wonders that where contra and metal slug. cute and well animated visuals won't save this stiff and harsh (and very tedious) try hard.

with every mission you go on, you have a stupid timer, with no real indicators as to where you have to go to find what you have to find (i only did 2 missions and gave up after a ton of stupid deaths).
the controls are fidgety and there is no diagonal shooting, which doesnt make sense b/c the game it is trying to pay hommage to had diagonal shooting (as well as super tight controls).

the one decent, though at the same time frustraing (and kind of stupid) concept is the weapon crafting system. you can customise every part of your guns... this would be fun and cool, but the resources are random drops from enemies and crates and you have to go over each item and 'duck' to pick it up, which sometimes puts you in harms way (dont forget that you have a timer as well and cant afford to die and/or do loot hunting).
there is also a death penatly (cash loss) and you have to restart from either the beginning, or a random tent you find lying around, which doesnt make things any more fun imo.

sound and visuals are decent, though nothing to write home about.

this game was on my radar for a while b/c it looked like a faithful adaptation of a childhood favourite of mine (metal slug 3) but alas, it is just a half baked wanna be that has since been abandoned (it was hyped up so much before official release and crowd funding and now the team has disappeared).

save your money or buy it when it goes dirt cheap (less then 50% standard retail would be good).

reviewText: This review was a close call for me, but I cant recommend the game right now. I love the style of the game, of course it reminds of games like Metal Slug and so on, but that doesn't make up for the repetitive and frustrating gameplay. There is a hub with missions, merchants and weapon crafting NPCs and things like that, which is cool, but the missions get way too annoying after a while. Especially because they use the same maps over and over, making you explore it again and again to get all the objectives done. What also drives me crazy is that enemies respawn all the time in the way of super old games like Ninja Gaiden, go too far in one direction and the enemy respawns is just not a good way in my opinion. The crafting system is cool, but doesn't really adds that much to the game. I really really wanted to like this game, but the repetitiveness and dull gameplay just can't convince me at all to recommend the game. I know its in beta, but they would need to change a lot to make up for it, which just isn't realistic. PS: Make the god damn multiplayer work at least...

reviewText:
I'm trying... so hard to enjoy this game.  I really, truly am.  I want to enjoy it.  It's actually pretty cool!  Controls are (mostly) tight, some of the music is catchy, the art style is lovely, and it's awesome for local multiplayer.  Plus I adore the weapon building system, aside from it being a little cryptic.
I just have a few complaints outside of that.

This game is VERY player-hostile.  Outside of the tutorial you have VERY LITTLE explained to you, and that's just not okay.  The first time I found an adrenaline shot I was stressing out because I had absolutely no clue what it did, only to find out when I accidentally rolled into a spike pit and died.  I thought it was a small health boost, but no, it's a revival item, and it's ESSENTIAL for co-op if you're inexperienced.
By the way.  This game also doesn't spend a second explaining co-op.  Not one word is spoken about it anywhere.  You have no way of finding out how it works other than looking it up online or figuring it out for yourself.  Bad.

Secondly: Difficulty spikes.  Just...  Why?  Why would you do that?  There's nothing wrong with making a game gradually more difficult.  It doesn't have to jump up all at once like this one does.

Third, I think a couple of the bosses could use some tweaking.  I'm not as far into the game as I could be, but I still feel at least a little justified in this.
Every boss should have a pattern that's easy to see, no matter how difficult.  A couple of the bosses in the game, yes, that's true.  But then there are other bosses that seem like they're impossible to figure out, and then when you do figure them out, it's impossible to avoid taking damage from them.
And then there's one boss in particular that literally can't touch you if you just stand on the edge of the barrier.  Seriously.  All you need to do is dodge every so often and you will not get hit.  That makes something that's supposed to be dangerous a mere waste of time.

I also think that the weight system could use some work...  It's okay if it affects your movement speed, but it shouldn't affect your jump height.  There were one or two occasions where, I kid you not, I actually got stuck and had to quit a mission because the gun I was using was too heavy.  Being weighed down into moving slowly is fine.  Just don't mess with the player's aerial mobility.  That doesn't work for a platformer.

And the elevators.
*sigh*
The elevators.  Once again with the player-hostility.  You are not told how elevators work.  The first time I saw them, I thought I had to move far enough away to trick them into moving, then jump on, because they don't move when you're close or standing on them.
After driving myself crazy over it for about fifteen minutes, I eventually figured out that you're supposed to press up or down while standing on an elevator to get it to move, depending on where it can go.  This is extremely awkward because there are times when you're standing on an elevator and need to duck to avoid incoming gunfire, only to send the elevator down with you on it.
(Also, to jump down through an elevator, you hold up and press the fire button.  Why?)

To sum it all up, long story short, tl;dr, would I recommend this game?
Not at full price.  It's not worth $20.  If you can get it on sale for $10 or less, I'd say check it out if it's your type of game.

reviewText:
You may seen this intro a lot in the review: I really wanted to like this game. Pixelated but colorful art, old school with a modern touch, etc... that's all truth and likeable. But I really had a problem with the gameplay, something that should be a star in this kind of games.

First, this does not play like Metal Slug in an aspect. May look like it, but is more like a cheap megaman knockoff. Yep, I'm this harsh because the scenarios and platforming is filled with lame and boring challenges, timed repetitive missions and enemies that are just not fun to fight.

Weapon crafting is still pretty good, and it may intrigue you what you can build with what you find, but honestly, this is the reason I usually don't dig in this kind of mechanic: I have to wade trough repetitive gameplay until it's grating. I might be compensated with building great guns and upgrades, but with such lame enemies to fight, what's the point? It's like playing XBlades in a Turrican-Megaman uninspired perspective.

If you want to play Metal Slug, it's here on steam. If you want to meet the untalented son of Diablo and Megaman, get this.

reviewText: Welcome to Metal Slug the job! Were you tired of playing Metal Slug with its good level progression and fun missions? Well look no further with fetch quest and grinding out the wahzoo! And as for weapon crafting all I truly remember was the pure tedium of crafting said weapon that usually is very unfun to use so instead of having these awesome powerups in Metal Slug which freshened the game up all you are left with is a tedius item screen and one weapon that usually took you hours upon hours of grinding the same stage. At the point of which the game costs it seems you could just play an mmo or something else with your money atleast you can chat with your friends online in that instead of this.

reviewText:
I can recommend this game, because I've been having a fairly good time with the basic gameplay... BUT.... a concession to the cautious buyer: the longer you play, the initial fun level begins to diminish as you begin to notice how the game extensively recycles assets and mission types. Mercenary Kings is perfectly content to repeatedly send you off on the same 3 types of fetch quests in one of the same 3 maps, over and over, again and again, for hours.

Mercenary Kings is the equivalent of that FPS you play that isn't really outstanding, but also isn't bad, and turns out to be a really great way to just kill a half an hour. It's a game you can hop into quickly, and missions can take anywhere between 5 minutes up to 30 minutes. If you're just looking to kill some time shooting a couple dudes while looking at some great pixel art, then Mercenary Kings fits the bill marvelously.

If you're a fan of old school side-scrolling shooters (e.g. Metroid, Contra, Gunstar Heroes, Cave Story), etc, then you're probably going to enjoy this game well enough to make it worth the purchase (especially at a sale price). There is **EVENTUALLY** (very, very eventually) a variety of ammo types, and it can be interesting discovering how different ammo types can have unique effects on certain types of enemies (e.g. when you shoot an enemy hiding behind a riot shield with caustic ammo, the riot shield melts away and changes the enemy's behavior).

However, I specifically say AMMO types and not GUN types for good reason. One of the most loudly advertised aspects of the game---and definitely one of the most attractive---is the ability to pick up various materials" dropped by enemies
date: which you can then sell for money or use at crafting stations to create new parts for your gun or various other perks. The game is very proud of these mildly RPG-esque and clearly Borderlands-derived elements
recommended: but the implementation is hit or miss. The ammo types are implemented pretty well. The gun parts... meh.\n\nAfter dumping over 10 hours into the game (and having a fairly good time
hoursPlayed: mind you)
voteText: and experimenting with different gun mods
helpfulPercent: my honest opinion is that the vast majority of craftable gun parts and passive skills are more or less pointless. The game undermines upgrades and customizations in the vast majority of cases by giving an upgrade with one hand while stealing it back with the other.\n\nFor example
votesHelpful: suppose you currently have a clip size of 8 and a damage rating of 150
votesTotal: and you want to upgrade your clip size to fire more shots before stopping to reload. The game might let you upgrade your clip size to 12
votesFunny: but it knocks your damage down to 100 and slows your walking speed. Suppose you decide to skip the clip size upgrade then and just upgrade raw damage? The game might let you boost raw damage to 200
commentsCount: but it will reduce your clip size to 4 shots and slow your walking speed. Or it might alternatively lett you have the 200 raw damage while reducing your magazine size to 7
column16: but the cost is your reload speed is now three times as slow.\n\nIn short
column17: most of the unlockable weapon parts aren't so much "upgrades" as much as they are like sliders that you can use to change CHARACTERISTICS of your weapon
column18: but which don't really IMPROVE your weapon overall.\n\nAlso
column19: you CAN'T SHOOT DIAGONALLY in this game. Which is annoying
column20: because enemies CAN shoot diagonally

column22: but the game makes you wish for that diagonal aim through enemy behavior suggesting that you should have it
column23: and then for some reason
column24: you don't. When I noticed that

Caustic bullets burn away at enemies (and sometimes melt away their defenses) while piercing bullets can travel through walls and objects to hit unsuspecting enemies on the other side. Piercing bullets can also travel through several enemies in a line. And
column29: of course

reviewText:
I've bought this game maybe a year ago in early access. The graphics are cute, and it seemed like a metal-slug kind of game.
The actual game is horrible, the gunplay tries to be smart with active reload, the jumping has a slight delay, and you receive damage from touching enemies - despite there being a melee attack.
There's some kind of material gathering and crafting, but the basic controls and gameplay feel like a game for kids.
It's not metal slug, it's not contra, it's not mightnight resistance, it's not even mario.

I had very high hopes for this game, but even with a controller the game is just not fun at all.

reviewText: So, first off - the game is beautiful, the animation is fluid and funny, the game has a ton of character, it's a Scott Pilgrim nod to Metal Slug.  All those things are great... but the gameplay.  EVERY mission is a timed variation on a fetch quest, and most of the environments look the exact same.  Timed missions ALONE would dissuade me from continuing, but I kept at it because I really wanted to like it.  I figured weapon customization would save the game, but alas, unless you make very specific weapons, they tend to be pretty worthless.  I was hoping for a Loadout-esque customization system, but the game really just wants you to buy parts to make a shotgun.  Or a sniper rifle.  If you get creative in any way, the negatives are so huge that it's not worth the effort - I went from a standard magazine weapon with 6 shots to a larger magazine, and my damage dropped about 80% - so though I had more bullets to a clip, I was doing far LESS damage with each shot.\n\nIf you can handle mazey fetch quests, give it a shot.  It's a solid backbone, it has a lot of things going for it, but it just felt too clunky and grindey to me.  Such a shame, I'd been looking forward to playing it for a while now.

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY IT! UNTIL YOU READ!! SERIOUSLY!!!
If you are expecting this game to be like Metal Slug, Metal Assault, or Contra. Turn away right now. The game is better with Controler (HIGHLY RECOMENDED) With Keyboard, it is hellish to play.
So this game seem to have something new to it's style, unlike METAL SLUG. This game offers Crafting weapons, buying items, character customization and varrious mission to play. Not to mention online co-op for friends to join.

SO WHAT WENT WRONG?!

Level Design choices

UNLIKE METAL SLUG, this game is a CHORE! Most of the mission is  fetch quest style mission. The first mission was finding ONE hostage. (seems okay) Then the game do the exact same thing for second mission WITH 8 HOSTAGES! By the way, it's on the same map. (OR it look very similar, which make the game feels repetitive)

YOU DON'T FEEL LIKE A BADASS!
This game is more difficult than Metal Slug, GOOD! However..., the game refuses to throw any retaliation! (I'm going to compare this to Metal Slug again.) In Metal Slug, you will encounter TANKS, 10+ Footsoilders, HELICOPTERs, and so on. This make the game fun, and give that satisfying feeling of destorying everything like any RUN n GUN game should be. But all you'll encounter in this game is just repetitive respwanable enemies. For example, sending 3 melee soldiers and die by 1 SINGLE BULLET. Or having 1 or 2 riflemen attacking you. Compare that to Metal Slug or Contra.

SLOW EVERYTHING IS SLOW.

The fact that this game force you to do search n destory, or fetching an objective. Forces you to wonder around the map trying to find that LAST GUY WHO YOU MENT TO KILL. Again, unlike Contra or Metal Slug, this game doesn't proceed quickly. Infact, it probably force you to GRIND. That's right, having a crafting system is good, but you need to grind for the materials. I don't want to do that, this is not an MMORPG. The game does give you in-game money allowing you buy items. BUT NOT MATERIALS. NOPE YOU GOTTA GRIND FOR IT. May I ask why!?

Combat Mechanic

Honestly, very disappointed. I'll make this short. Why is there a reload mini game? Does it have any purpose? It was more like a punishment rather than FUN. I mean, reloading itself is already difficult. Or maybe it's not difficult in this game? BECAUSE THE GAME HARDLY throw enemies at you! While it adds abit of challenge during boss fight, I find it more... annoying. There's no real reward for hitting the right time for reload minigame, but only punishment when you hit too early or too late. I rather just hit reload and just wait. Other than that the mini game mechanic, is a waste of space.

Final things I would like to add.

WHY DO I ONLY HAVE A PISTOL!? Where's my nade?
WHY IS THERE A TIMER!?
WHY DOES IT COST MONEY TO DIE?! Isn't losing one life not enough!?

For PC, IF YOU HAVE NO CONTROLER! DO NOT BUY!! Was expecting something like Metal Assault, which was an MMO but have a very good mechanic, you can use your mouse to aim, and shoot with LF-Click. SIMPLE!? Why didnt the developer think of this?!?!


Buy, at your own risk. Good Day.

reviewText:
I purchased this game when it came out because it essentially looked like Metal Slug, and I loved that series of games. Those were fast-paced and interesting. This game, however, is not. When I first started playing, I learned quickly that it had no joypad or mouse support. I can understand having no mouse support since you only fire in four directions. You could always use third party programs to play with a joypad, but joypad support is something that you find in pretty much any game on PC made past 2008 or so. It's probably the game's single largest missed opportunity.

And the reason why it's such a huge missed opportunity is because the keyboard is possibly the worst method of playing. The learning curve is enormous on a game that doesn't need the complexity this game has. When you're not struggling with learning the eighty million keyboard shortcuts, you're going to be struggling to learn things like weapon customization. Which, by the way, is almost completely useless. It's a lot of work for little reward. Speaking of rewards, the missions in the game are glorified fetch quests and get tedious very fast.

The only saving grace of this game is essentially the online multiplayer. If you can find friends to tolerate the game enough to learn the basics and play with you, it can be fun enough to tolerate for a while.

If you love Metal Slug enough to slog your way through the opening hour or two, by all means, purchase the game. Otherwise, wait for a Steam sale that brings the game down to around $5 or so. 'cause, frankly, that's about how much the trouble you'll be getting yourself into is worth.

Easily in my top ten games I wish I hadn't supported monetarily.

reviewText:
For fans of the classic SNK arcade series Metal Slug be fore-warned, this is nothing like it.
The game pretends to be like Metal Slug with it's visual aesthetic mainly by its featured artist, Paul Robertson, yet does not accurately capture the cartoony animations of the series in any way. This is not to say it looks bad, but for all of us that hope to see a giant crab with a cannon mounted to its back, your better off looking elsewhere. Where Paul Robertson's style worked wonders in the Scott Pilgrim VS the World game, in Mercenary Kings the visual just look boring and Robertson's bad habit of copying and pasting the same face on many of the women really shows here.
The gameplay is even less like Metal Slug and is more akin to being like Monster Hunter with it's weapon crafting system as well as the hunting and gathering aspects of the game. This wouldn't be something negative if it weren't for the fact that Mercenary Kings itself is  just boring to play. Now most games are repetetive in some way but most games also find a way to mix up the repetition in at least a small way. In theory, Mercenary Kings should be able to keep the gameplay fresh with its different types of missions, but as soon a mission begins the player will end up shooting the same enemies, collecting the same loot, meet the requirements, rinse and repeat. Sometimes there will be a boss type enemy to give the player something new to shoot but nothing honestly changes the overall gameplay and it really starts to become a chore throughout. It's a shame because Mercenary Kings showed promise with the team behind the Scott Pilgrim game as the developers, alas not all that glitters is gold and for that you can easily spend your $20 elsewhere. If you really want to give Mercenary Kings a shot though then wait for it to go on sale for at least $10 or lower.



TL/DR Ver.: If you want a Metal Slug type game to get your fix just play Metal Slug or Alien Hominid.

reviewText:
First off, they wont let you rebind keyboard controls, so that's already a big middle finger for anyone who doesnt have a controller.

Many times i have managed to scape the level twice or three times to find my objective just for the timer to run out and start it all over again.
I can't believe how anyone would spend over 10 hours playing this game without boring themselves to death. But, i have to give them credit for the artstyle, it's very charming and a throwback to ye olden days.

reviewText:
First, I'll start by addressing the cons many people mention. This game does revisit the same areas. What it does right about this mechanic is that it will often lock certain areas of that map until you clear specific missions, and the variety of the missions more than make up for this.

The crafting and customization that a person can use to suit their playstyle is varied enough to suit anyone's taste. Homing guns, projectiles that explode with shrapnel on impact, piercing rounds, elemental rounds, and even player buffs that can make a melee build one of the most lethal.

The multiplayer co-op is the most fun feature of this game. Whether local or online, the players are free to explore separate areas of the same map, versus locking you in the same screen (as does Metal Slug, a game that cleraly inspired this one). The only negative part that players may find is that local co-op is split screen, so plan to be close to the screen if it is not a large one. Also, players can leave whenever they feel like it (even the host) without forcing other players to quit, and players can join at any point in between missions.

The most impressive ascpect of this game is the commitment that the developers have to ensuring that it is a great game. Their persistence in ironing out bugs is rare for an indie team. This is reason enough to buy the game, and to buy future titles from this team.

Graphics are one of the last thing I care about so long as the game works, and it does. On that note, the art style in this game is fantastic.

TL;DR: Lots of crafting and player build customization, varied missions, drop in/drop out co-op campaign, great art style/graphics, dedicated developer team.

9/10

reviewText:
Metal Slug meets Monster Hunter? Oh hell yeah!

If you're a Monster Hunter passionate, such as myself, you will definitely LOVE  this title. The feeling you get is very close, and a lot of mechanics are present in both games:
Weapons can be forged, and they come in various shapes and colors. Not only that, but weapon parts are divided in categories which alter the way they work.
The main area is a small village, where all the NPCs live. Many of them also resemble ones from Capcom's franchise: the general who gives you missions, the cook who... erm, cooks you food (which gives fixed AND chance-based bonuses), the gunsmith who forges all your gun parts from monster materials, and so many others.
Areas work similarly to how they do in Monster Hunter, being divided in zones and having enemies indigenous to them. However, in this game most enemies tend to respawn as soon as they leave your field of view.
Oh, and I didn't talk about boss fights yet! Bosses can be killed OR captured, and overall the pattern-learning process behind defeating them for the first time feels the same.
Then comes CoOp. You can play together with up to four people, and you all share the same lives. There's a built-in voice-command system, too.
I could go on, but I hope you get the point.

If, however, you're considering buying Mercenary Kings for the Metal Slug part, you'll be slightly disappointed: while it mantains all the glorious 2D shootin' goodness, it lacks a bit of the fast-paced and action-packed gameplay that makes Metal Slug what it's well known for. Also, there are no power-ups scattered around the map or dropped by your foes, for instance.

Overall? I don't even know where to begin: some great but not overly complex pixel-art, an amazing soundtrack, interesting characters, an addicting gameplay and the CoOp mode are all important points that give a strong first impression.
Maybe it's not really worth €20, but you should totally get it if it drops below €15.

reviewText:
Mercenary Kings. The game that could have been good.

Metal Slug meets Monster Hunter, how could that be bad? Easy. The development team is full of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.
The game mechanics are slugish and unresponsive making the game slow and stiff. This becomes an issue durring the many glitched boss fights, fights that are nearly impossibly without a second players help to exploit the boss' patterns.  This is to say, the game is hard. But not hard in a way like Dark Souls or Mario, where it is your fault when you die, but in the most unfair of ways. A good example is a later level where there are falling platforms over spikes and offscreeen enemys fire at you durring your jump arc from one falling platform to another. Your options are get shot and take damage, or fall and take damage.

This is my issue with the developers. Between being too lazy to fix old content before adding in things nobody asked for like pizza statues for a tent that serves no purpose and pulling bull ♥♥♥♥ like making art and stories for each member of the playable characters team only to tell the players who bought the game excited to play as them that they are all dead in the story and the guy and girl characters are the only ones you can play and you should be happy about it. Oh, but they had enough time and money to make the sprite art for their own personal sprites for a circle jerk achivement at the end of the game.

All developer ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t aside. Is the game good? No. Any of the Metal Slug games are a better purchace for the same or cheaper price. The only thing this game does new is blend RPG progression with a slow and stiff side scrolling shooter, and it doesn't even do that well.

reviewText:
i missed any sort of hype leading up to the release of this game, but two days ago my friends told me to get it. and so i picked it up and played it for about 13 hours straight.

friend: how was your easter?
me: i spent it playing merc kings
me: didnt even leave the house
friend: well that's an accomplishment i guess
friend: you should post that on steam as a game review

although a little buggy, this is a fantastic game. theres just enough variety in the mission assignments to keep it interesting, and the maps are wonderfully big. but really the biggest draw is the art. the pixel art style is often used to market games towards older types of gameplay, but here the art is just a fantastic medium for a game. robertson has done a lot of pixel art berfore as art, and even for the scott pilgrim game. here we see a great show of the same quality work he is known for. if you dont mind spoilers, you can view some gifs here http://probertson.tumblr.com/post/82062175084/mercenary-kings-animations

tl,dr; its a fun game, especially with friends, to waste some time with. and youll never get tired of watching the sprite animations

reviewText: Now with mappable controls! This game combines everything that is good in an old arcade game! Mercenary Kings combines the aesthetic of a game like Metal Slug and Scott Pilgrim, into a rootin-tootin-gun-shootin lootfest and arcade sidescrolling shooter! The game also impliments what I call a 'borderlands-lite' version of gun customization: Want a regular gun? Sure, but, what about a gun that shoots homing acid rockets? GO FOR IT! This game promotes crazy gun builds and RPG crafting elements to make youre own favorite weapon of carnage and destruction! Build a gun, go in with 4 player local coop or multiplayer, and take down CLAW!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Does blasting an army of bad guys to smithereens Metal Slug-style sound like your idea of a good time? How about doing it with your own custom-made weapon using whatever mishmash of parts you can think of? If any of that appeals to you, then this is absolutely worth a shot.

Paul Robertson's handmade sprites and backdrops do a lot to give the experience that retro/fake-retro charm without coming across as just pixelated for the sake of it. The soundtrack's combination of metal and chiptune-like tones calls to mind things like Virt's compositions for Contra 4 and DuckTales Remastered.

Once you get some momentum going, it's lots of fun crafting gun parts, bionic mods and even substitutes for your trusty knife, to put together your own personal loadout and see how it performs.

There's a couple hitches though. To me at least, the system of equipment weighing you down seems out of place, and the Monster Hunter-type layout of missions giving you different objectives in the same areas means it can get kind of repetitive, especially if there's a gun part or something you REALLY want to get the materials for.

Trifles aside, it's a fine example of mashing together run-and-gun violence and strategic weapon crafting.

reviewText:
Mercenary Kings is a strange beast. It’s like the unusual lovechild of the aging, but still strangely attractive Metal Slug and its sleek, modern boytoy Borderlands, but being raised by the GGG Contra after Borderlands refuses to take custody of the child.

Let me explain: You play as the Kings, a batch of mercenaries that were sent to Mandragora Island to defeat CLAW, a strangely Nazi-esque group conducting strange experiments in advanced technology and some-such. In the process, you die, but are revived with the help of a special Mandragora serum, developed by CLAW to make super soldiers. And that’s about where any semblance of plot lies. You have a cast of kooky characters that are little more than hyperbolized caricatures (Cute female weapons specialist? Check. Caffeine-addicted, one-eyed general? Check. Australian blade expert and all-around outdoorsman? Check. You get the idea), with a lot of gaming and pop-culture references that are entertaining, if not particularly fulfilling.

You can read more over at http://thumbthrone.com/reviews/mercernary-kings-oddly-beautiful-old-school-violence/

reviewText: So far so good!  For the old school gamers who came up on platform shooters like Contra, you'll LOVE this.  It's as if Contra, Metal Slug, and Loadout made a baby.  I know I often mash up games like this for my review, but I like to be as vivid as possible to make sure you fully understand.  The basics of Contra, the humor and style of Metal Slug, and the customization of Loadout is what you will get.  Unlike platformers I've played in the past, this one allows each player to take their own path!  No more compromising on which way to go first so that the other player doesn't get killed or stuck by the edge of the screen.  The only downside to it so far, is the time limit for each mission.  There's so much I want to explore within the level, and it's easy to forget about the time limit on completing your objective.

reviewText:
Mercenary Kings is an incredibly faithful exploration of retro gameplay, modernizing out many of the shortcomings of the games of yesteryear. It features gorgeous pixel art reminescent of the 16 bit era, heavily inspired by the arcade classic Metal Slug, and a glorious chip-tune soundtrack.

One might expect Mecenary Kings to fully lift the run-and-gun stylings of Metal Slug given it's style and theme, but instead it actually picks and chooses a wide selection of mechanics from the Mega Man franchise. It notably draws on the Mega Man Zero and ZX series, with a wide selection of collected gems from across the earlier titles.

The game features missions with a variety of optional challenges that are a delight to revist with different armaments; the same level feels different when approached for speed or when explored thoroughly for resources, and players are well rewarded for become familiar with enemy patterns, level layouts, weapons and items.

I was actually very surprised when I started joining in on multiplayer efforts with how wonderfully multiple players integrate, and just how diverse the weapon selection is among players. While it seems natural for players to gravitate to a single weapon layout to me, it turns out that there is little consensus between players on what equipment works best; clearly the weapon crafting system does an excellent job of addressing individual play styles. There is something for everone.

There are some short comings. It is difficult to construct weapons that utilize the unusual ammo types, generally forcing one basic gun type; stocks and sights don't really contribute much to weapons overall except to craft weapons for very specific ammo types. Biomods and Proficiencies are good overall, but there are a wide range of abilities that just aren't present. It's not that the options available aren't significant, it's just that there is a great deal of options that could be added, like modifications to rolling, or jumping (like double jumping). It feels a lot like the more unusual options aren't present for the certainty of avoiding game-breaking bugs or opporunities; it's not bad but it feels overly safe".

reviewText:
Many of you are probably leery (as I was) about dropping 20 bucks on this game. I hope that this review will help you make your decision. The game is certainly not for everyone, but I will go into it's pros and cons shortly.

First, I would like to adress many of the complaints I have seen in other reviews.

Many seem to think that the controls are clunky. This is true- at first. after 30 minutes or so of gameplay, the controls seemed natural to me. If they really bother you, you can always remap them quite easily. I also read many reviews which stated that the jumping seemed unresponsive. The only time I have noticed this is when I have attempted to jumo when in a prone position (laying down). Otherwise, the jumping mechanic seems just fine to me.

Some also complain about the reusing of maps. I can certainly see why some people may become irritated by this, but it doesn't bother me. Since you're always completing a different mission, the maps do not seem too repetitive.

Let me just say that Mercenary Kings is a fantastic game that deserves a lot more attention than it is currently getting. The retro-style gameplay combined with the endless weapon customization makes for one of the most enjoyable gameplay experiences I've had. The character animations are worthy of an award, and the maps and backgrounds look fantastic. I'm not too far into the campaign, but so far it has been fantastic. At first, it may seem overly difficult, but if you just do some part swapping with your gun, you should be fine. I will update this review with some of my favorite beginner weapon setups soon.

The only thing I have found irritating about this game is the lack of a chat menu in multiplayer games. This is extremely minor, however, and will most likely be fixed in a later update.

Overall, I would highly reccomend this game to anyone looking for a great retro-style gaming experience. It's well worth the $20. I hope this review was helpful to all of you ladies and mentlegen.

13/10

reviewText:
The GoodAs advertised, this is a 2D shooter / scroller / run around the map a roller with plenty of gun customization.
The music is pretty good and the pixel art graphics and animations done by Paul Robertson, among the best in that field, are absolute eye-candy to look at. If you've ever played or seen Scott Pilgrim Vs. The World The Game on consoles, you've seen some of this guy's work already. The basic gameplay works fine enough with you jumpin', runnin', knifin' and shootin' (not diagonally though) through an assortment of levels with a bunch of goodies hidden about. When you get into the groove and master the controls it can definitely trigger some nostalgia from cartridge/arcade cabinet days of yesteryear.

The BadTo deck out those guns and upgrade your gear, you're going to have to do quite a bit of grinding for ingredients (random drop or otherwise). Expect to revisit a bunch of areas for this purpose and have to deal with monotonous mission objectives, time-limits and silly boss fights where you have to worry about tracking them down across the whole map to fight them some more until they die if you take too long. All while the timer ticks down in the background. No pressure to find your way to one of those boss arenas scattered about the maze-like maps while the boss periodically shuffles around (leading to some particularly cruel instances where you can finally make it to a boss-zone where it's at and it just walks away after three seconds) or anything. There may additionally be some problems with the game on certain monitors or comps but I didn't personally run into this myself

The UglyEven with this game's short-comings, there IS fun to be had. As such, there is definitely an audience or two to reccomend this to. Just be prepared to have a bit more Monster Hunter in your Metal Slug sandwich than you perhaps initially bargained for. Replace the Mission Complete jingle with the one from Metal Slug via files for maximum irony while you're at it, too.

reviewText:
Gameplay in the Mercenary Kings consists of players embarking on various quests to hunt or capture specific monsters. Players are able to choose from a wide variety of weapons, each catering to a specific style of combat.

The primary goal of the game is to complete quests by successfully hunting or capturing powerful monsters, retrieving their parts through carving or receiving them as rewards, and using them as materials to craft or upgrade armors and weapons.

Unlike most traditional RPGs, players do not level up" and must instead rely on obtaining better equipment for improving their characters. Players are also not restricted by job/class systems commonly found in other RPGs. Instead
date: they are able to freely switch between different weapons
recommended: each offering a different playing experience."

reviewText:
I went into this game expecting contra/metal slug. It wasn't...

I played for a good hour and while the game is really nice looking I found it lacking where it counts: Fun gameplay.
Games like Contra or MS are instantly fun the second you play the first level. But this was just a very unsatisfying experience for me.
It wasn't fast. It wasn't very action packed. I had to reload all the time. All enemies were in annoying places. A lot of backtracking. It just felt so clunky all the way through...
Even talking with NPCs felt slightly awkward.

And this may sound silly, but I really disliked the control setup and evnen had a hard time changeing them. Again, the setup felt so awkward. I was also very surprised to see a game of this type use such an abundance of control buttons. I expected two or three besides the arrow keys.

If this game didn't have it's great graphics and music there'd be absolutely no reason left to play this as the game itself is poorly excecuted in my opinion.

reviewText:
First, I can't completely understand the comparision with Metal Slug beyond the mercenary-war theme of the game, honestly... this felt quite original for me and nothing like MS -granted the visual and certain similarities between the main characters of each game caught me on the first try, but still-, so if you're expecting something like Metal Slug, well.. is not, it's different. MK is fresh and unique on its own terms, enough to stand alone as the great game it is ^^

The gameplay and the story went all together smoothly for me, I just got caught in the action and completely willing to help the Mercenary Kings ^^ The music rocks and the animations are delightfully smooth even for a game that lurks intensively on the retro-look ^^ The gun-customization and overal RPG-like aspects of the game only place you deeper into the action, keeping it surprising and endearing, and this comes from someone who generally doesn't like RPGs ^^u

Totally recommended =D

reviewText: A simple metal slug clone this is not. While the gamplay is similar, the depth here appears huge. With a multitude of weapon parts to buy using resources you scavenge while gunning down a horde of different enemy types.\nYou'd think it would be hard to get bored of such a game, however while there are (in the end) a large number of levels, each stage forces you to play through the latest two over and over, rescuing hostages this time and destroying the generator that time... but the objective is a moot point, the journey from start to finish is the same from level to level.\nIt's a shame since at times the pacing is great, set pieces work well and bosses are challenging... but eventually it all boils down to shoot, jump, reload, repeat. And 20hrs of that is asking too much.[5]

reviewText:
This game is incredibly fun. Think Monster Hunter + Metal Slug. You kill enemies which drop resources that you use to build parts for guns, build melee weapons, or make mods which give various effects. Granted, most missions are gathering missions, but there is a small variety. Sometimes you will need to kill a boss, or even capture it with Shock Bombs when it is low on health.

You only shoot in the cardinal directions, which I am fine with. It would be too easy if you could aim diagonally. The jumping takes a bit to get used to. Just as a reference, think Batman on the NES. The jump works almost the exact same. A slight delay before jumping, hold it down to jump higher, and once you're in the air you can alter the trajectory slightly.

Most missions have bonus objectives, and every mission has Secret objectives which are only revealed once you have found/killed whatever the secret objective is related to. Bonus and secret objectives offer bonus money and resources.

This game is very grind-heavy, since you have to hope for resource drops, but it's much more forgiving than a lot of other games. Some missions offer a few of a specific resource, or the mission actually requires you find that resource. A simple look through the resource guide in the community hub can help you find that elusive resource.

I'd recommend this game to any fan of Metal Slug-style games, or even just side-scrolling shooters. Hell, I'd recommend it to anyone, really. As always, if you're not sure, watch some gameplay videos of it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Platforming old-school style! This is classic style gaming at it's finest. It brings back memories of game arcades and early home consoles.

The mechanics are a bit primataive (no diagonal shooting) but the game seems well ballanced around that.

The story is also classic. You fight an evil organization bent on...world domination? Terrorists? Bad guys for sure at any rate. You start play as one of two previous mission/story survivors brought back to life by a specially formulated serum, which is probably why the island you are on was invaded in the first place. Everyone wants it.

Gather the items your enemies drop when defeated and use them to create new weapon parts and other implements of destruction and warfare. Missions pay well the more successful you are, some even have bonus objectives. You can buy supplies (rations, first aid kits etc.)  to take with you into the field or chance finding what you need as you go.

Games were never this complex in the old days since back then, it was all about the high score. Modern game design, such as the custom weapons, keep the game fresh in modern times.

reviewText:
Pretty good game. At first I was incredibly impressed by how polished and wonderful it looks (because it does - it has that fantastic Metal Slug feel to its presentation), and by how fun the simple gameplay is. It's a lot of fun to traverse the non-linear levels, and most enemies are pretty fun to fight and kill.

However, after playing for a few hours, I started to realize how much content is recycled, and how tiring it got that every mission is just a fetch quest. On the same couple of levels. This hit especially hard when I played a mission where you have to hunt down a boss that keeps escaping to different points on the level, making him almost impossible to find let alone kill (I had to find him four times in random spots before I was able to wear him down). A few missions later, they recycled the *exact* same boss and level, with the only difference being that you had to stun and capture him or something.

I really wish the game didn't have so much excess padding, because it could've been one of my favorite indie titles ever. I have a few other gripes, such as the fact that it's pretty bad at explaining how all the customization works, and if you finish the main objective in a level you get no chance to finish the secondary before leaving. Also, the reload mechanic slows down the pace a lot, and makes single-shot guns very unfun.

Still, it's a strong game at its core, and tons of fun outside of the annoying moments. It's not worth its full price because you're gonna get sick of it pretty fast, but on a sale for like 3-5€? Sure.

reviewText: Mercenary Kings is one of the few games that depicts how only a few mechanics can throw a monkey wrench into what could have been a great game. From the start you are given a game that is a mix of Monster Hunter,Metal Slug, and a dash of Gears of War. In theory this sounds quite awesome! In practice it shows how each one of these mechanics can work against each other.\nStarting with the Monster Hunter mechanic of finding loot to craft new guns, this forces the player to grind in a side scrolling shooter. At first it dose not seem to be an issue up until you face the 2nd boss in which kill you. Or in most cases, will time you out. Causes you to replay stages for better weapons because bosses in the game can run away from you if you don't kill them fast enough. Next is the two other mechanics described in which can work against each other.\nDue the reload mechanic you will be taking shots and you have no way to defend yourself. This could have been fixed with an instant reload rather than the timed reload. Adding another layer of frusteration. I tried going in wanting to love it. Even through the time on greenlight I tried holding hope. Sadly I can't say it is fun sadly. I give Mercenary Kings a 6.5/10.

reviewText:
This game isn't what you think it is.

You probably think it's Metal Slug with customizable guns, which sounds fantastic.  I'd love to play that game.  That's not what this is.  You're not going to run around like a maniac blowing up everything around you.  What you're actually going to do is move carefully forward so you don't get hit, explore every corner of the map over and over, and ultimately get tired and give up.

The main gameplay loop is that you have to move carefully or take damage, which is *very* expensive to repair, and many of the missions involve finding 10 of something on the map...and there's only 10 to find.  And they're not listed on the map.  So you end up exploring the map over and over until you have 9 of 10 collected and you can't find the last one, so you end up going over and over the map, taking damage and dying until eventually you either run out of lives or out of time, and these missions aren't short.  You will put a HUGE ammount of time into these missions and fail them over and over.

Plus you can't alt-tab out of the game, so you can't even look at FAQs or maps to help you.

The game doesn't make you feel strong, it makes you feel like a chump.  The grind takes forever and unless you enjoy finding items scattered and hidden all over the same map over and over, you'll eventually grow to hate it.  I did.  I can't recommend this game.

reviewText:
So what is Mercenary Kings?  One part Metal Slug, with an inventory and crafting system, with that familiar 4 player game play.  Either for a 'serious' play, or casual, it's honestly fun.  Great old school handling and the soundtrack is a nice mix of classic bit work and modern rock.

The inventory and crafting systems are pretty simple.  You need X amounts of Y materials to craft Z part for your gun.  Plus some cash.  And for those of you who like to customize and build and have MULTIPLE gun builds? They have you covered.  Everything from pistols, carbines, assault rifles, shotguns, machine guns, toilets, and trombone's (to name a few), with elemental ammo, armor piercing, buckshot.  Lots of options here for scoring some ludicrous gibs (yes!).  OH and knives too. But who needs a knife when you can build a freakin' minigun?

The game handles well, overall. You move your character, and they get there.  Feels like something taken right out of an arcade cabinet and put into your hand with such simplicity it's nuts.  Any fan of the Metal Slug franchise WILL feel right at home here.  You needn't worry.  For everyone else?  This game is quick on the uptake.  You shall find no sloppy handling here.

My one issue is that the default input is a keyboard. I would highly. HIGHLY recommend the use of a game pad.  Otherwise the keyboard controls are a bit spaced out and kindof irregular.  The gamepad makes everything RIGHT at home.

Overall, for a game that's in 'early access' it feels fairly rock solid and fairly 'done'.  Yet they keep adding to and tweaking the game.   And the price tag certainly makes this a worthwhile investment.

reviewText: This is Metal Slug shooting meets Risk of Rain level-crawling with a hearty helping of Loadout-style weapon crafting. Slightly difficult to get used to the controls at first, as the character takes a brief second to jump, and you only have 4 directions you can aim. The levels feel a little repetitive, as the levels have multipule missions within a single area to complete, ranging from killing certain amounts of specific enemies, to collecting crafting materials, or simply talking to an NPC on the map. Some minor annoyances are enemies respawning the moment they leave the screen, and the limited aiming range, but for a side-scrolling shooter with up to 4-player multiplayer capabilities, there's quite alot to offer.

reviewText: Whats not to like about this game? Very smooth animations and backgrounds that are easy on the eyes, and pretty varied in terms of how much they reuse backgrounds. The pacing of the game is all around perfect giving you enough time to explore the worlds they make but still haivng a time limit give a sense of urgency. There are so many NPC's to talk to and get new items such as food that gives you temporary boosts, a place to buy usables in a mission such as healthpacks, a place to buy mods that help your character, and much more. Of course the best part of this game is the ablity to mix and match oarts for your weapon to make a gun that truly fits your playing style. Want a gun that acts like a shotgun but has a machinegun clip go ahead, want a gun that looks like a trombone, why not right. And of course you will get to use all of these varied weapons on the extremely varied enemies and bosses in the game that are too many to count. Play this game by yourself or with friends either way will be a challenge that you can enjoy.

reviewText: This game is mediocre at best. The strong point of the game is the customization of the guns and a very workable multiplayer online experience (from when I played through it with my friend) but that is about it.\n\nThe game relies on getting materials to make weapons as the driving force for replayability. The missions take place in stages with very slightly different objectives, like fetch X amount of material, rescue X hostages, or kill X enemies in one specific area. The platforming feelings awkward and clumsy, but later levels shoehorn it in or damage must be taken by stage hazards. The combat feels slow as enemies feel like they have tons of HP for the sake of it (might have been from playing 2 man multi and always splitting up). Many of the bosses are elemental re-skins and any interesting ones come too late in the game and too infrequently for one to care. I feel this game is in an odd spot where it has the look and feel of attempting to be a game like metal slug or contra, but lacks the level design and style to do it. the gimmicky ammo is cool the first time or two, but doesn't really do much that is exciting after the small ooo ahhh" factor is gone. 2/5"

reviewText: There is a ton to love about this game. There's challenging levels, metal slug/megaman-esque gameplay with monster hunter supply gathering, the best pixelated sprite work I've ever seen, fun multiplayer online and splitscreen, and a staggering amount of gun, knife, and character color customization. I haven't encountered any bugs at all either. The game also features tons things to keep it challenging. Little babies who can't deal with a time limit or interesting reload systems on missions should go play a first person shooter. They made it so you can time your reload just right and get an attack bonus, you almost have to strategize in some situations. Do you wait to hit green and get a damage boost but risk getting hit? Or do you hit the yellow and pump your foes full of lead right then and there? The best way this feature works is with it's cover system. (yes, hitting down to duck behind a box should be considered a cover system) And the fact you can't shoot diagonally isn't much of a big deal either. The fact that enemies can isn't bad game design, it keeps you on your toes kiddies. Those same things happen in metal alug, enemies can shoot diag. and you can't. But the fanboys of the neo-geo classic will nit-pick Mercenary Kings all day for it not being an exact copy of M.S. The gameplay may be similar, but you need to walk into the game knowing the two games differ quite a bit. There are some RPG elements etched into M. Kings as well in upgrading your guns, armor and misc. equipment.  There is grinding involved, but that's part of the experience. Not everyone can be a badass overnight, you have to work for it. These are things you need to consider before purchasing the game however, you shouldn't blindly charge into the store and buy it because you think it's metal slug, because it's actually not.\n\nOverall, this game can provide hours of engaging gameplay and an experience that can be enjoyed by yourself or with your friends.

reviewText:
A solid 2D action game.  Some may describe it as a run and gun, but it has a much more deliberate pace.  While the learning curve may initially be a bit steep, the game provides a moderate challenge all the way through.  Rush or play carelessly and you will be punished.  The game expects you to learn the patterns of your enemies.  Positioning and purposeful movement are key.  The controls are crisp, but a controller would be highly recommended in this case.  I played using a Wii U Pro controller.

It is broken up into short missions which can usually be completed in 5-10 minutes each.  These missions are on a timer, but for the most part these timers are very generous.  However, if you are the kind of player who cannot stand having time limits you may want to avoid this game.  The missions come in a number of varieties.  Collect materials, kill a boss, clear out the enemies, or reach a destination.

The art is incredibly well done, the entire game looks great.  The sound track can be quite catchy too.  The presentation is superb in every way.

The gun crafting system is can be quite entertaining for those who like to tinker.  While initially the options are limited after completing a few ranks you can start mising and matching.  Machine guns that shoot bouncy balls, fire based shotguns, and electric homing missile machine guns are all possible.  You can find a weapon to suit your style.  While Shotguns and Sniper Rifles are a bit dominate in the early game as you progress pretty much everything becomes viable.

If you are willing to put in a little effort to learn the game it will be a solid experience.  However, you need to be ready for a game that can be a bit challenging and does not hold your hand.

reviewText:
This game will steal your time and suck you in! No really.
At first I was quite sceptic about the idea of playing a retro game, a few let's plays later I shelled out the money for the beta version of the game. Now that it is complete I can safely say that the money I've spent on this game was worth it (and I still haven't finished it). I haven't played Metal Slug, but who cares about that game anyway? Mercenary Kings is a deceptively simple run and gun game, until you realize that you will have the most fun grinding levels just to get that one last ingridient for the dream gun. You will laugh your pants off when you notice all the subtle or obvious nods to modern action cinema (one of the knives is called Trejo and it isn't a Machete, the Machete references a Federale Cortez).
If you are interested in the story, MK has one and it is as over the top as the rest of the game, especially if you wait long enough to see the intro (look out for the IV drip).
If you are still reading this you should stop, buy the game and play it. CLAW won't stop itself you know...

TL;DR Version - Fun, Good Value for the Money, Long and Hard enough to be worth it.

reviewText:
Originally I thought this game was going to be like Metal Slug. It has the animation styling of Metal Slug sure but this is more along the lines of Contra/Castlevania. Platforming requires skill and forethought. The influences of Monster Hunter and Borderlands are evident. The crafting system being the basis of this game and the Borderlands influence being the weapons themselves and their parts.

I will warn people now, this game is not for everyone. There's a patience to it, the run and gun occuring very rarely. It stands up more as a co-op shooter with everyone in their mother having ridiculous guns that shoot fire and cause people to explode all over the floor. This is late into the game though. It breaks down to first finding a style of gun that suits how you want to play, followed by working your way through it.

The questing system is exactly like Monster Hunter. Fetch Quests are plentiful but the farther in you get the more the game begins to open up and you start having to clear whole sections of the map. The time element only comes into play very early as they get more generous as the game continues and more so as the maps get wider. You spend time on every map and you begin to learn the different nooks and crannys of those maps as you go.

Overall I recommend this game if you enjoy crafting, hard side-scrolling games and maybe a bit of animation. It has a story that's flat and a little eh but it does move along. Gameplay seems monotonous but that's mostly based on watching, playing, the hours tend to fly by. Its usually best to play this in shortish bursts as long stretches will become exhaustive I've found.

It's repetitive and somewhat sluggish, but very charming.

reviewText: Cute and fun game that's an awesome experience in co-op. Takes a lot of influence from old classics (Contra, Mega Man, Metal Slug), but also includes features inspired by newer titles. There's lots of background and secrets, and the crafting system is pretty extensive (though I agree with the disappointment of some other reviewers of the locked gun-type paths).\n\nOne critical thing I have to note though, to be able to enjoy this game, you're definitely required to have compatible gamepads!

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game to anyone who was, or is, a fan of metal slug. This game uses similar mechanics, but also does away with intsa-death, for you and your enemies.

It also adds further depth with customization options, such as knife-type, gun-types, ammo-types, and bionic mods (akin to passive boosts).

Although the campaign does run a acceptable length of time, some people may find the levels repetitive - you are required to do several missions (about 7) per area, and you will revisit the same areas. There are 108 enemies, so enemies repeat.

The music is great though, I certainly didn't mind listening to the same track often.

Overall, I'd say that even though the game has some repetitive elements, I found it very enjoyable, completed the game, and did not regret a single hour of my time. If you're a fan of 2D platform-shooters, this is definitely for you!

reviewText: Note: This recommendation was made in July 27th, 2013 during Early Access and this recommendation is only made in mind that this is NOT the final product.\n\nI've played a good few hours into Mercenary Kings. Overall, it is a fun game if you're into the Metal Slug kind of gameplay mixed with Loadout's Depth of Weapon Customization (changing head, body, bottom of a gun with sight + ammo) with the Monster Hunter's Mission Rule Set of 'Three Strikes and you're Out' and it's 'RPG-like' drop-rates. There are way too many guns to customize so experimenting what kind of gun you like is the fun part. Since this game focuses more on the 'gunplay' than any other part, if you are coming from Scott Pigrim vs. The World Video Game, the 'melee' part of the game is a bit lackluster since there are basically three different ranges of melee. Short, Medium, and SPEAR LONG. There's no 1-2-3 combo built behind them, it's only a melee swing.  The other issue is that exploring is a bit discouraging when it comes to examining what's inside the houses. 80% of examining the inside of a building results nothing. Followed by 10% Indoor Level that's fleshed out and 10% there's a guy you have to rescue in there! However, the outdoor exploration is vast and nice to roam around. Soundtrack is somewhat limited, but it's in Alpha state atm. Is it worth 15$ (current price)? If you really want Metal Slug/Run and Gun Retro-Style arcade game and miss Tribute, the same guys who made Scott Pigrim, sure give it a shot. Multiplayer makes it exponentially more fun without ruining the game. There isn't even an option mode at the moment so you have to adjust the sound through the Volume Mixer. The price tag for 15$ may sound a bit steep for the penny pinchers. 10$ would be fair, but prices excluded, the game does what it does right: Executes Metal Slug while adding Gunplay Customization that feels just right.
voteText: No ratings yet
No ratings yet

reviewText:
So what is Mercenary Kings?  One part Metal Slug, with an inventory and crafting system, with that familiar 4 player game play.  Either for a 'serious' play, or casual, it's honestly fun.  Great old school handling and the soundtrack is a nice mix of classic bit work and modern rock.

The inventory and crafting systems are pretty simple.  You need X amounts of Y materials to craft Z part for your gun.  Plus some cash.  And for those of you who like to customize and build and have MULTIPLE gun builds? They have you covered.  Everything from pistols, carbines, assault rifles, shotguns, machine guns, toilets, and trombone's (to name a few), with elemental ammo, armor piercing, buckshot.  Lots of options here for scoring some ludicrous gibs (yes!).  OH and knives too. But who needs a knife when you can build a freakin' minigun?

The game handles well, overall. You move your character, and they get there.  Feels like something taken right out of an arcade cabinet and put into your hand with such simplicity it's nuts.  Any fan of the Metal Slug franchise WILL feel right at home here.  You needn't worry.  For everyone else?  This game is quick on the uptake.  You shall find no sloppy handling here.

My one issue is that the default input is a keyboard. I would highly. HIGHLY recommend the use of a game pad.  Otherwise the keyboard controls are a bit spaced out and kindof irregular.  The gamepad makes everything RIGHT at home.

Overall, for a game that's in 'early access' it feels fairly rock solid and fairly 'done'.  Yet they keep adding to and tweaking the game.   And the price tag certainly makes this a worthwhile investment.

reviewText:
This game is incredibly fun. Think Monster Hunter + Metal Slug. You kill enemies which drop resources that you use to build parts for guns, build melee weapons, or make mods which give various effects. Granted, most missions are gathering missions, but there is a small variety. Sometimes you will need to kill a boss, or even capture it with Shock Bombs when it is low on health.

You only shoot in the cardinal directions, which I am fine with. It would be too easy if you could aim diagonally. The jumping takes a bit to get used to. Just as a reference, think Batman on the NES. The jump works almost the exact same. A slight delay before jumping, hold it down to jump higher, and once you're in the air you can alter the trajectory slightly.

Most missions have bonus objectives, and every mission has Secret objectives which are only revealed once you have found/killed whatever the secret objective is related to. Bonus and secret objectives offer bonus money and resources.

This game is very grind-heavy, since you have to hope for resource drops, but it's much more forgiving than a lot of other games. Some missions offer a few of a specific resource, or the mission actually requires you find that resource. A simple look through the resource guide in the community hub can help you find that elusive resource.

I'd recommend this game to any fan of Metal Slug-style games, or even just side-scrolling shooters. Hell, I'd recommend it to anyone, really. As always, if you're not sure, watch some gameplay videos of it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Platforming old-school style! This is classic style gaming at it's finest. It brings back memories of game arcades and early home consoles.

The mechanics are a bit primataive (no diagonal shooting) but the game seems well ballanced around that.

The story is also classic. You fight an evil organization bent on...world domination? Terrorists? Bad guys for sure at any rate. You start play as one of two previous mission/story survivors brought back to life by a specially formulated serum, which is probably why the island you are on was invaded in the first place. Everyone wants it.

Gather the items your enemies drop when defeated and use them to create new weapon parts and other implements of destruction and warfare. Missions pay well the more successful you are, some even have bonus objectives. You can buy supplies (rations, first aid kits etc.)  to take with you into the field or chance finding what you need as you go.

Games were never this complex in the old days since back then, it was all about the high score. Modern game design, such as the custom weapons, keep the game fresh in modern times.

reviewText:
Pretty good game. At first I was incredibly impressed by how polished and wonderful it looks (because it does - it has that fantastic Metal Slug feel to its presentation), and by how fun the simple gameplay is. It's a lot of fun to traverse the non-linear levels, and most enemies are pretty fun to fight and kill.

However, after playing for a few hours, I started to realize how much content is recycled, and how tiring it got that every mission is just a fetch quest. On the same couple of levels. This hit especially hard when I played a mission where you have to hunt down a boss that keeps escaping to different points on the level, making him almost impossible to find let alone kill (I had to find him four times in random spots before I was able to wear him down). A few missions later, they recycled the *exact* same boss and level, with the only difference being that you had to stun and capture him or something.

I really wish the game didn't have so much excess padding, because it could've been one of my favorite indie titles ever. I have a few other gripes, such as the fact that it's pretty bad at explaining how all the customization works, and if you finish the main objective in a level you get no chance to finish the secondary before leaving. Also, the reload mechanic slows down the pace a lot, and makes single-shot guns very unfun.

Still, it's a strong game at its core, and tons of fun outside of the annoying moments. It's not worth its full price because you're gonna get sick of it pretty fast, but on a sale for like 3-5€? Sure.

reviewText: Mercenary Kings is one of the few games that depicts how only a few mechanics can throw a monkey wrench into what could have been a great game. From the start you are given a game that is a mix of Monster Hunter,Metal Slug, and a dash of Gears of War. In theory this sounds quite awesome! In practice it shows how each one of these mechanics can work against each other.\nStarting with the Monster Hunter mechanic of finding loot to craft new guns, this forces the player to grind in a side scrolling shooter. At first it dose not seem to be an issue up until you face the 2nd boss in which kill you. Or in most cases, will time you out. Causes you to replay stages for better weapons because bosses in the game can run away from you if you don't kill them fast enough. Next is the two other mechanics described in which can work against each other.\nDue the reload mechanic you will be taking shots and you have no way to defend yourself. This could have been fixed with an instant reload rather than the timed reload. Adding another layer of frusteration. I tried going in wanting to love it. Even through the time on greenlight I tried holding hope. Sadly I can't say it is fun sadly. I give Mercenary Kings a 6.5/10.

You even go on missions in a Monster Hunter-ish format. For those who aren't familiar with one or either of the aforementioned games, Mercenary Kings is a 2D side scrolling run 'n' gun adventure where you take on the role of King" or "Empress"

reviewText: Is this a great game in the traditional sense? Debatable. There's definitely the skeleton of an amazing game, but it's hard to deny that the flesh is basically made out of bone. Like the whole thing is just a really really thick skeleton...\nWhat I'm trying to say is that the game is samey as ♥♥♥♥. Like pretty badly. The boss fights are nicely varied, but the missions in between are just... you'll know a map front to back at the end of it's related rank, that's for damn sure. The crafting system, while not terribly unique, really adds a sense of depth and personalization to the game, and lets you set goals for yourself, which is always a plus in my book. But the reason I recommend this is not any of that.\nI'm giving this a recommendation because it is just a much cooler version of Metal Slug, and I like Metal Slug. I might not want to play it all the time, but when I do this game is there for me with a mission I haven't completed the fastest time on or a new gun that I haven't beaten a boss with or just something, anything, to give me an excuse to play a very functional, responsive, fun 2-D scrolling shooter. And at the end of the day, that's worth the 20 (15 if you have friends) dollars.

reviewText: It's like if they took metal slug, and took out all the fast paced fun and creativeness out of it. Not to mention the sprite work doesn't even come  close  to the artistic prowess of metal slug. That, and I can't even get past the first level. Maybe I'm dumb but I went searching high and low for a way to progress and couldn't find it. I'm sure at this point I could look up guides, but the lack-luster gameplay will keep me away from this in the forseeable future.

reviewText: It's fun if you like repetitive platformers where you have to learn the enemy patterns to defeat them. Missions are timed, death is frequent and failure is just around the corner. Reloading your weapon is an annoying minigame, you can only shoot up/left/right, down only if you jump up first, making some enemies far more dangerous because they can shoot/move on the diagonal. You have to grind to get items to unlock and EVERYTHING has to be unlocked.\n\nI found it frustrating and a waste of time. But someone will like it. It's a good game for the genre, I suppose, but it's not for me.

reviewText: Now with mappable controls! This game combines everything that is good in an old arcade game! Mercenary Kings combines the aesthetic of a game like Metal Slug and Scott Pilgrim, into a rootin-tootin-gun-shootin lootfest and arcade sidescrolling shooter! The game also impliments what I call a 'borderlands-lite' version of gun customization: Want a regular gun? Sure, but, what about a gun that shoots homing acid rockets? GO FOR IT! This game promotes crazy gun builds and RPG crafting elements to make youre own favorite weapon of carnage and destruction! Build a gun, go in with 4 player local coop or multiplayer, and take down CLAW!

reviewText:
Does blasting an army of bad guys to smithereens Metal Slug-style sound like your idea of a good time? How about doing it with your own custom-made weapon using whatever mishmash of parts you can think of? If any of that appeals to you, then this is absolutely worth a shot.

Paul Robertson's handmade sprites and backdrops do a lot to give the experience that retro/fake-retro charm without coming across as just pixelated for the sake of it. The soundtrack's combination of metal and chiptune-like tones calls to mind things like Virt's compositions for Contra 4 and DuckTales Remastered.

Once you get some momentum going, it's lots of fun crafting gun parts, bionic mods and even substitutes for your trusty knife, to put together your own personal loadout and see how it performs.

There's a couple hitches though. To me at least, the system of equipment weighing you down seems out of place, and the Monster Hunter-type layout of missions giving you different objectives in the same areas means it can get kind of repetitive, especially if there's a gun part or something you REALLY want to get the materials for.

Trifles aside, it's a fine example of mashing together run-and-gun violence and strategic weapon crafting.
